messages.text: Are you there? Sarah?
So are you just going to ignore me?
Please.
*sigh*
Just let me talk. I know what you think you saw.
IDC
Hear me out. You won’t answer your phone. You won’t answer your door. This is all I have. You don’t have to type. But please don’t go anywhere. I have a lot to explain.
Yes? No?
Thank you.
I love you Sarah. I want to marry you. I want to wake up every morning and feel your warmth. I want your good and your bad.
Everything.
CWOT
It will be worth your time.
I’m sorry. I’m overly emotional right now.
Sarah, I remember thinking, before we even spoke, after seeing you from across the room, that you were the one. I just knew.
Never had a doubt.
Now here we are.
I am a private person Sarah.
I have kept things from you.
Important things.
CU
NO! You HAVE TO LISTEN. I’m begging.
K
I told you my mother left when I was ten, and my dad took care of me. Here’s the real story.
When I was nine, they sent all the kids home from school early because the heater broke and it was freezing outside.
I got off the school bus, went home, and found my mother sitting on my bed weeping.
I put my arm around her and asked what was wrong.
She said, “You’re a sweet boy, Davey, but you ruined my life. I never wanted children. Your father was adamant. Now my life is over.”
“I’m a talking corpse.”
Then she nearly smiled and said, “I used to be such a good dancer. You should’ve seen me. I had dreams before you were born. I was going to BE someone.”
I was confused. This was my mother. The person who was supposed to love me the most.
I told her she WAS someone. My mother.
Then she said, “I’m pregnant again. I can’t go through with it. Your father wouldn’t be able to look at me ever again if I had an abortion. I need to go away so he won’t have to look at me.”
She did not look like herself. Her eyes were dark, red, wet. Her lips trembled. Her face had lost its color.
She told me I shouldn’t exist. She told me she used to bang her stomach against the wall hoping to miscarry.
Told me she once threw herself down the stairs.
WTF!
I know.
Mom hastily packed a suitcase and left without another word.
I never saw her again.
Dad came home and asked if I’d seen Mom. I lied. Said I hadn’t.
To this day I haven’t told him what she told me that day. I have kept the pain to myself. In my heart.
It’s why I have never believed I’m good enough. Certainly not good enough for you.
It’s why I freaked out over the miscarriage last month. I thought maybe you did it on purpose. That you somehow made it happen.
I was having flashbacks of my mother.
I was wrong to have compared you to her for even a second.
For that, I am so sorry.
It was despicable. I realize now your grief was even greater than mine.
You lost a part of yourself.
Your pregnancy brought back thoughts of my mother. Bad thoughts.
If you can understand that, I’ll move on with the rest.
Thank you.
Now the girl. Beth.
She knocked on my door a few hours before you got there.
I opened the door and she stared at me. Then she cried. Then hugged me.
She was so overwhelmed she could barely speak. But in those few silent seconds, I realized something.
She sort of looked like me. Once I looked past the bright blue hair and all the piercings.
The nose. The eyes. The dimples.
But no. No way! That’s what I was thinking. My mother had been so cold to me and so disgusted with the idea of another pregnancy.
Could I actually have a sister?
Before speaking, with the tears flying off her face like rain, she pulled out an old wrinkled picture.
It was my mother, still looking sad and vacant. She was holding a newborn baby.
A baby girl.
The back of the photo had TEXAS ’89 written on it in faded ink. The timeline matched.
OMG!!!
I invited this girl in. I started crying myself. Finally she was able to talk.
My mother had nowhere to go and ended up in Texas. Maybe she picked a destination at random.
A woman found her passed out on the sidewalk.
The woman, Jennifer Caulfield, took my mother in. My mother told Jennifer about the pregnancy. How she didn’t want the baby.
Jennifer and her husband had been trying for years to have a child with no luck.
Jennifer told my mother she would take the baby and raise it as her own.
Amazingly enough, my mother agreed.
Sarah, I have a SISTER.
This is real.
She’s funny and beautiful and a smartass in the best possible way, and she’s been searching for me for years.
She’s a performance artist, if you can believe that. I guess art runs in the family.
Well, if you consider my comic books art.
NC
Ha! Not funny.
Anyway, when Beth was a year old, Mom vanished. Gone in the night.
Mom will always be a mystery. Perhaps that’s best.
The Caulfield’s did exactly as they said they would and raised Beth as their own.
Raised her spectacularly.
They told Beth the truth. All of it.
And she found me.
I let her take a shower while I went to grab us dinner.
I didn’t call you because it seemed like the kind of news you tell someone in person.
Then you arrived and found Beth in a towel.
Now here we are.
I have never been happier. I can finally come to terms with my past, while having this amazing new person in my life.
I can’t wait for you to meet her.
You’re going to laugh when you see me. My smile won’t go away.
I look like The Joker. Nicholson, not Ledger.
I, David Fredericks, want to spend my life with you, Sarah Devlin. From this day forward.
Always.
Forever.
Unconditionally.
Share this life with me.
Hello?
My heart is pounding.
Please say something…
I love you
Madly
Come here
NOWs
DaveNSarah went offline
